awd_abstract_narration:
With five years of funding from the NSF Scholarships in Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics (S-STEM) program, the University of Scranton will provide scholarships to 25 students who have demonstrated financial need and academic achievement. The scholarships will support students who are pursuing bachelor's degrees in the STEM disciplines of biology, chemistry, computing science, mathematics, and physics/electrical engineering. Key features of this program include common seminar courses for the scholarship students to help them develop an identity as a member of the STEM community, outreach activities with local schools, and an independent research experience supervised by faculty trained in mentoring. 

The goal of this project is to recruit, retain, and graduate 25 low-income students in STEM disciplines. The project will provide scholarships that will offset the expected family contributions to their education. The program will focus on developing students' STEM self-efficacy through 1) shared seminar courses, 2) mentoring based on research-backed multi-mentor models, 3) training in problem-solving tactics, 4) undergraduate research experience, and 5) structured cohort-building activities in and out of the classroom. Measures of outcomes including retention and placement after graduation will serve as indicators of project effectiveness. Measures of the quality of faculty and peer mentoring and the effect of multiple mentors on student success will contribute knowledge relevant to development of other programs aim on improving the participation of low-income students in STEM.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
With funding from the National Science Foundation’s Scholarships in Science, Technology, Engineering and Mathematics (S-STEM) program, the Royal Scholars: Transforming STEM in Northeastern Pennsylvania, provided support to low-income students with demonstrated financial need and academic promise to succeed in STEM disciplines at The University of Scranton. The project funded 27 scholarships over 6 years for students who were pursuing bachelor’s degrees in STEM. Key features of the program included common seminar courses for Royal Scholars to help them develop an identity as a member of the STEM community, retreats for first-year students at a local environmental research and education foundation, outreach activities with local schools, and an independent research experience supervised by faculty trained in mentoring. 

The goal of this project was to recruit, retain, and graduate 25 low-income students who had talent or potential in the STEM disciplines of biology, chemistry, computing science, mathematics, and physics/engineering at The University of Scranton. Students were provided with scholarships to offset the expected family contributions to their education. These Royal Scholars received mentorship and support services to provide a path for success in STEM majors and to develop their identities as STEM professionals. STEM self-efficacy has a major impact on the retention and graduation rates of non-traditional STEM students. Current research and best practices have shaped the approach to mentoring and the role of an undergraduate research experience for STEM students. Thus, the program focused on developing students’ STEM self-efficacy through shared seminar courses that incorporated research-backed practices of multi-mentor models and of problem-solving tactics, an undergraduate research experience, and structured cohort-building activities in and out of the classroom. Measures of outcomes, including retention at the University and within a STEM major, as well as placement after graduation, served as indicators of the effectiveness of this project. 

The primary program outcome of retaining students in STEM was met. Retention to the second year was 100% (25/25), compared to a typical rate of less than 80% for low-income first-year students in STEM fields. As of spring 2023, 18 of the 20 students who had entered the program and were of the graduating class of 2023 or earlier graduated in a STEM major. This is a four-year graduation rate of 90%. As of spring 2024, 21 of the original 25 students in the program remained in the University and graduated in STEM majors; a graduation rate of 84%. This program has produced substantially higher rates of retention and four-year graduation rates of economically marginalized students in STEM fields than is typical. In addition, our data indicate that growth in science self-efficacy, including over the COVID disruption, was a hallmark of this program.

The structure of support and sense of belonging within a cohort of STEM scholars greatly enhanced the students’ potential to graduate and continue on to a STEM career or graduate studies. 

 


Last Modified: 07/29/2024
Modified by: Janice Voltzow
